generif.text: demonstrate that two biological fluids, blood plasma and seminal plasma, differentially activate LPA receptors
results suggested that LPA(2) and LPA(3) may be involved in VEGF expression mediated by LPA signals in human ovarian oncogenesis
LPA may directly increase the level of cyclin D1 in ovarian cancer cells, increasing their proliferation.
Upregulation of LPA2 may play a role in carcinogenesis, particularly in postmenopausal breast cancer.
LPA2 is the major LPA receptor in colon cancer cells and cellular signals by LPA2 are largely mediated through its ability to interact with NHERF2.
formation of the LPA receptor/PDZ domain-containing RhoGEF complex plays a pivotal role in LPA-induced RhoA activation
These results demonstrate that MAGI-3 interacts directly with LPA(2) and regulates the ability of LPA(2) to activate Erk and RhoA.
EDG4 and EDG2 cooperate to promote LPA-stimulated chemotaxis in breast tumor cell lines.
data suggest that LPA receptor-dependent expression of CTGF and CYR61 represents a common host response after interaction with bacteria.
lysophosphatidic acid 2 receptor mediates down-regulation of Siva-1 to promote cell survival
A role for the transgenic lysophosphatidic acid (LPA)2 receptor is identified in regulating smooth muscle cell migratory responses in the context of vascular injury.
LPA and LPA receptors, LPA(2) as well as LPA(1), represent potential therapeutic targets for patients with MPM

Expression of LPA2 during ovarian carcinogenesis contributes to ovarian cancer aggressiveness, suggesting that the targeting of LPA production and action may have potential for the treatment of ovarian cancer.
Switching of LPA receptor expression from LPA3 to LPA1, may be involved in prostate cancer progression and/or androgen independence
LPA(1) receptor, LPA(2) and LPA(3) receptors-induced VASP phosphorylation is a critical mediator of tumor cell migration initiation
LPA2 and Gi/Src pathways are significant for LPA-induced COX-2 expression and cell migration that could be a promising drug target for ovarian cancer cell metastasis.
Data show that CLL cells express LPA receptors LPA(1-5) and VEGF receptors, and the plasma levels of VEGF are elevated in CLL patients.

show that human microglia express LPA receptor subtypes LPA(1), LPA(2), and LPA(3) on mRNA and protein level. LPA activation of C13NJ cells induced Rho and extracellular signal-regulated kinase activation and enhanced cellular ATP production.
LPA2 gene mutation may play some role in the pathogenesis of colon cancer.
MAGI-3 competes with NHERF-2 to negatively regulate LPA2 receptor signaling in colon cancer cells.
This work shows for the first time that key components of the LPA pathway are modulated following traumatic brain injuries in humans.
found that LPA receptor 2/3-mediated IL-8 expression occurs through Gi/PI3K/AKT, Gi/PKC and IkappaB/NF-kappaB signaling
LPA2 and LPA6 receptor subtypes are predominant in both HPAECs and HMVECs
Lysophosphatidic acid (LPA) increased hepatocellular carcinoma cells cell invasion, which was LPA-receptor dependent.
LPA1 and LPA2 are major LPA receptor subtypes compared with low-expressed LPA3 in PANC-1 tumor cells.

Crystal structure of NHERF2 PDZ1 domain complex with C-terminal LPA2 sequence. The PDZ1-LPA2 binding specificity is achieved by hydrogen bonds and hydrophobic contacts with the last four LPA2 residues contributing to specific interactions.
the RhoA-regulated formin Dia1 is involved in entosis downstream of LPAR2
Suggest that LPA2 and LPA3 may function as a molecular switch and play opposing roles during megakaryopoiesis of K562 cells.
Data show high expression levels of LPAR2 and LPAR1 in endometrial cancer tissue with positive correlations with FIGO stage suggesting them as potential biomarkers for endometrial cancer progression.
LPAR2 mRNA is up-regulation in colorectal cancer.

epithelial dysplasia was observed in founder mouse intestine, correlating LPA2 overexpression with epithelial dysplasia. The current study demonstrates that overexpression of LPA2 alone can lead to intestinal dysplasia.
The results indicate that LPA2 and LPA3 receptors play opposing roles during red blood cells differentiation.

LPA2 mRNA levels were associated with poorer differentiation, and higher LPA6 levels were associated with microvascular invasion in HCC; both became a risk factor for recurrence after surgical treatment when combined with increased serum ATX levels

LPA2 expression was associated with HIF-1alpha expression and that a high level of LPA2 was associated with shorter overall survival and was an independent prognostic predictor for breast cancer in Chinese women.
These results suggest that LPA signaling via LPA2 may play an important role in the regulation of cellular functions in HT1080 cells treated with cisplatin.

Study shows that due to the high LPAR2 and LPAR4 transcript and protein expression in endometriotic ovarian cysts and positive correlations of both these receptors with the PR-B and ERbeta, respectively, those receptors seem to be the most promising predictors of the endometriotic cysts.

Investigated the roles of LPA receptors in the regulation of cellular functions during tumor progression in osteosarcoma cell lines. MG63-R7-C cell activities were inhibited by LPA2 knockdown, suggesting that LPA signaling via LPA2 plays an important role in the acquisition of malignant properties during tumor progression in MG-63 cells.
LPAR2 and LPAR5 regulate cellular functions during tumor progression in fibrosarcoma HT1080 cells.
It was revealed that LPA may stimulate the expression of Notch1 and Hes family bHLH transcription factor 1, and the phosphorylation of protein kinase B which belongs to the Notch pathway.

The positive expression rate of LPA2 and KLF5 were statistical different in gastric adenocarcinoma, GIN, and normal gastric tissue (P<0.05). LPA2 positive expression was associated with tumor invasion depth, Lauren type, vascular invasion, local lymph node metastasis, and clinical stage (P<0.05).
Effects of lysophosphatidic acid (LPA) receptor-2 (LPA2) and LPA3 on the regulation of chemoresistance to anticancer drug in lung cancer cells.
Roles of endothelial cells in the regulation of cell motility via lysophosphatidic acid receptor-2 (LPA2) and LPA3 in osteosarcoma cells.
Transcriptional regulation of lysophosphatidic acid receptors 2 and 3 regulates myeloid commitment of hematopoietic stem cells.
BRET analysis reveals interaction between the lysophosphatidic acid receptor LPA2 and the lysophosphatidylinositol receptor GPR55 in live cells.
LPAR2 correlated with different prognosis and immune cell infiltration in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and kidney renal clear cell carcinoma.
Estrogen-increased SGK1 Promotes Endometrial Stromal Cell Invasion in Adenomyosis by Regulating with LPAR2.
LPAR2-mediated action promotes human renal cell carcinoma via MAPK/NF-kappaB signaling to regulate cytokine network.

positive regulation of cytosolic calcium ion concentration
positive regulation of Rho protein signal transduction

name: lysophosphatidic acid receptor 2
other_names: endothelial differentiation, lysophosphatidic acid G-protein-coupled receptor, 4

biocarta.name: rho-selective guanine exchange factor akap13 mediates stress fiber formation

kegg.name: Phospholipase D signaling pathway - Homo sapiens (human)
Regulation of actin cytoskeleton - Homo sapiens (human)
Pathogenic Escherichia coli infection - Homo sapiens (human)

summary: This gene encodes a member of family I of the G protein-coupled receptors, as well as the EDG family of proteins. This protein functions as a lysophosphatidic acid (LPA) receptor and contributes to Ca2+ mobilization, a critical cellular response to LPA in cells, through association with Gi and Gq proteins. An alternative splice variant has been described but its full length sequence has not been determined. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
